Text: If they got rid of the \n tree, what about the \n treasure!?
The tree... It's gone...
What do you mean?
He sounds like a \n wonderful man.
He was always so \n curious and so \n kind... I miss him.

That sounds like a 
 plan. Studying is hard 
 work, but it'll pay off 
 in the end.
Ah, so that was the \n gift his grandpa \n gave him!
I hope I can be like \n him someday.

I want to see the world 
 and solve its mysteries! 
 I'd better study hard to 
 pull it off.
It's okay, Grandpa's \n already given me my \n treasure.
And tell me to "study, \n open my mind, unlock a \n brighter future."
He used to bring me \n here...
It's a Grigo Station!
I forgot all about that.
Learn so you can be \n whatever you want to \n be...
Take the Boy and Find \n the Place in the Photo
Something \n seems wrong...
Heya! What are you doing \n here? Wanna talk?
What do we have \n to talk about?

Wow, he's a 
 little cold... 
 I need to think 
 of something...
Oh, hey! What's that \n picture of?
It's a picture my \n grandpa left me.
A souvenir?
When I was little, he'd \n always play with me.
But when I went off to \n study, we stopped \n spending time together.
And before I knew it, \n he was gone.
So that's why you were \n looking down.

He wrote something on 
 the back, I've always 
 wondered what it 
 meant...
Do you know \n the place in this \n picture?
Hmm, wonder what \n he was trying to say.
How about I help you \n find that place?
You think we can? The \n picture's pretty old, \n so much has changed.
That just makes it more \n interesting! We've got a \n mystery to solve.
Boy: \n It's dark in the picture, maybe the park's on a lower level?
Boy: \n I think there was a park somewhere near the broadcast tower.
Boy: \n If you find the place, can you take a picture and show me?
Boy: \n I think you could see the park from a bridge under construction.
A bridge under construction... Think there was on that way.
Boy: \n That looks familiar, take a picture.
Boy: \n I thought it was around here...
Boy: \n That doesn't look right.
Boy: \n Close, but something's not quite right...
Boy: \n Close, but something's not quite right...
Boy: \n This is the place!
Boy: \n I can't see too well, maybe try to get closer?
Boy: \n I don't see it, but I know it's around here somewhere!
Boy: \n Maybe try a different angle?
Boy: \n Could you try taking the picture from farther back?
I have to take the boy with me.
I need to find that place from the picture!
Hm? Is this the place?
Boy: \n I think there was a park below us.
I have to take the boy with me.
Is this the spot?
It has to be... Things \n have changed, but \n I think we found it.

Come to think of it, 
 I think this is 
 where Grandpa used 
 to bring me to play.
You know, he bought me \n a balloon once, but I \n let it get away.
I remember it getting \n stuck under that roof. \n Boy, I cried and cried.
But he got it down for \n me and just patted me \n on the head.
Oh, you mean that roof \n over there?
Hey... There's \n something stuck here.
A... picture?
There's something \n written on the back of \n this one too!
You found it this time, \n but will you be so lucky \n the next time?
Your grandpa really \n must've liked puzzles.
He was always thinking \n of new games for us to \n play.
But when I went \n off to study...
I'd better stick \n around and help \n keep his spirits up.
Alright, looks like we \n have our next challenge \n then!
Is this the right place?
Things have changed a \n bit, but I think so.
I used to sit on this \n bench and listen to \n Grandpa's stories.

Like about how the 
 World Pillar came to 
 be, or what was at the 
 top of it...
Or where the manholes \n under the city lead...
Hm? Speaking of \n manholes, there's one \n right here.
Wait! Are you sure you \n should be opening that!?
A-Are you okay?
I'm fine, no worries. \n And look, here's another \n picture!

This time the pillar 
 and a tree are in it. 
 There's a note on 
 the back too.
You have come to the \n last riddle. What you \n find here is yours.
Hey, you think there \n might be a treasure!?
That tree... I think \n I've seen it before... \n But where?

I'll take us up so you 
 can have a look around. 
 Maybe it'll jog your 
 memory.
Hey, how about you help \n me find the next spot?

You think I can find it? 
 The picture is pretty 
 old, and so much has 
 changed.
That's what makes your \n grandpa's riddles \n interesting!
Hmm... A tree isn't much \n to go on, is it?
Wait... \n I remember now!

When I was small, I 
 wanted to run away from 
 my parents who always 
 wanted me to study.

To get out of studying, 
 I asked my grandpa to 
 sneak me out of my 
 room.

One day, my parents 
 found out and told me I 
 was never to see my 
 grandpa again.
It wasn't his fault... \n It was all mine.
I see... But I don't \n think he would blame you \n for what happened.
Before they stopped him \n from seeing me, he'd \n take me to a spot...
I think it's the one in \n this picture.
I might be able to \n remember where it is...
If you do, tell me and \n we can look for it.
You found it! This is \n the place!
Great!
I used to come down \n these stairs and play on \n the tree-
Huh?
Boy: \n Downtown is in the picture's background.
Boy: \n I think it was near an empty lot...
Boy: \n When you find the place, grab a picture for me.
Boy: \n I think the empty lot was near the factory.
The factory was over that way, wasn't it?
Boy: \n Hey, that kinda looks like the place, grab a picture.
Boy: \n I thought it was around here...
Boy: \n That doesn't look right.
Boy: \n Not quite right...
Boy: \n Not quite right...
Boy: \n No mistaking it, this is the place!
Boy: \n I can't see too well, maybe try to get closer?
Boy: \n I don't see it, but I know it's around here somewhere!
Boy: \n Maybe try a different angle?
Boy: \n Could you try taking the picture from farther back?

Hm? Is this the right area?
I have to take the boy with me.

Hmm, nothing but a tree to go on...

Boy: \n If you looked up, you could see a billboard with a pigeon.
Boy: \n I think the billboard was for the post office.
The post office, huh? I think it was that way.
